title.narrative: Life saving COVID19 prevention and response in White Nile

description.narrative: This project integrates health and WASH activities to deliver a comprehensive response to the outbreak at both the community and health facility level, in one isolation center in Rabak, in six hospitals in Kosti, Edduweim, Tandalti, Rabak, Al Getina and Al Gableen, and in six clinics in Guli, Kosti, Eduiem, Rabak Tandlati and Umremta localities. the targeted locations which have been identified in consultation with the communities, SMoH, WHO and other key stakeholders for the COVID-19 response at state level. Protection and gender will be mainstreamed across the project and all of the proposed activities have been designed with consideration for the specific needs of adolescent girls, children, women, people with disabilities and elderly persons in mind. The project intends to strengthen existing health systems, to ensure they are able to manage the COVID-19 response but also ensuring that they are able to deal with any cases of communicable diseases that occur. This will be achieved through capacity building and training as well as provision of equipment and PPE for health staff. In addition the rehabilitation of WASH facilities and provision of hand washing stations will result in improved hygiene practices at the community and health facility level. The provision of the WASH facilities will be accompanied with hygiene and health awareness campaigns and behaviour change communication through radio broadcasts and the distribution of IEC materials to sensitize communities on how to prevent the spread of COVID-19. The intervention has been designed and agreed in consultation with the SMoH, WHO, at state level. The implementation of activities will follow the MoH and WHO guidelines and project teams will closely coordinate with the targeted communities, health staff, SMoH and other COVID-19 response actors. The project will reach 5000 people directly and 340,000 indirect beneficiaries( 187,000 children 50% boys and 50% girls) and 153,000 adults (91800 women and 61200 men)
